stream_context.summary: Kaze iterates on the first overworld of Return to Yoshi’s Island, mainly parts 2 and 3.  Work centers on coin placement, climb routes, and a new beach area that houses a fog-shrouded ghost-ship entrance tied to a lighthouse puzzle.  A large portion of the stream becomes a live coding session to prototype dynamic, distance-based fog on N64 hardware.
level: Overworld – part 3 (beach, ghost ship, zoo entrance)

development_findings.summary: The overworld is split into 15 sub-areas; today Kaze blocked out parts 2 and 3 and confirmed traversal links to parts 4, 5, and 6.
Part 3 hosts a ghost ship that is initially unreachable due to dense fog; clearing a lighthouse later in the game removes the fog and unlocks the level entrance.
development_findings.quote: You go up the lighthouse, you turn the light, the fog disappears and now you can enter the level.

development_findings.summary: Implemented a custom fog system that increases opacity based on (a) distance to the ship and (b) camera angle; entering the inner radius hard-fades to white and respawns Mario on shore.
development_findings.quote: When you get within the warp range of the ship, your screen is going to fade to white and you’re going to be washed ashore.

development_findings.summary: Kaze’s personal engine now replaces nearly every vanilla SM64 subsystem: rendering coins as true models, quaternion animation, full camera, custom collision, water, walking physics, etc.; only some Mario action logic remains vanilla.
development_findings.quote: The only thing that’s still left from the vanilla 64 is Mario’s physics… even walking is custom code now.

development_findings.summary: He is midway through writing a replacement operating system to remove Libultra for performance and legal reasons and is also planning a new sound engine.
development_findings.quote: I’m actually working on reworking the operating system right now… I would have to update the sound engine if I wanted this to be legally sellable.

development_findings.summary: Considering embedding a minimal Python-like interpreter as a scripting language, claiming it could outperform hand-written assembly in some memory-bound cases.
development_findings.quote: I think about using [Python] as an interpreter language… you could save a lot of data throughput and potentially improve performance at the cost of CPU.

development_findings.summary: Visual design notes: prefers natural barriers (rocks, banana-shaped cliffs, ruined castles) over endless cliff walls; part 8 will feature destroyed castles referencing Yoshi’s Island; giant fruit will gate some paths.
Biobak will later replace placeholder backgrounds; Kaze therefore imports simple skies for now to aid layout.
Target coin count for the first overworld is being raised; easier wall-kick alternatives (rock steps) added for accessibility.
development_findings.quote: I fear some people… will not even understand what a wallkick is.

context_findings.summary: Kaze sees contrast—levels players dislike—as crucial to good pacing.
context_findings.quote: Sometimes the part that people least like about the game are also the parts that are most necessary to make the game's design work.

context_findings.summary: Expresses anxiety about aging cognition; says his neurons are now ‘optimized’ for game-design tasks instead of pure math.
context_findings.quote: Sometimes I feel like I’m getting older and my brain doesn’t work like it used to… maybe my neurons just got more optimized and less variable.

context_findings.summary: RTYI is a passion project with no commission money; other hacks like Drug Boss Mario are paid work.
context_findings.quote: Anytime I make a ROM-hack that… isn’t RTY, then it’s a commission game; this one here is not any paid work at all.

context_findings.summary: Frustration with third-party tools (NVIDIA Broadcast, OBS) repeatedly crashing mid-stream.
Cautious about leaks; first wave of beta testers for Drug Boss Mario limited to long-time community members.
context_findings.quote: During the first beta testing I'm only going to accept people that have been here for a long time because I want to minimize the chance of leaks.

biobak.summary: Has already reworked the Zoo area visually and is slated to overhaul all overworld backgrounds and skyboxes.
biobak.quote: Biobak is going to rework all levels here… Zoo did get a rework already so that’s why it’s looking better.

zeina.summary: Provided some brief feedback/approval in chat and shared art progress off-stream, but no direct technical input this session.

key_stories.title: Cracking N64 Fog Limits for the Ghost Ship
key_stories.summary: Kaze needed convincing volumetric fog to gate access to a ghost-ship level. The N64’s fixed fog functions clipped at 1000 units, and naive billboard methods killed performance.
key_stories.challenge: Achieve localized, dense fog without tanking performance.
key_stories.process: Prototyped a custom GLSL-style macro: fog alpha scales with distance & camera yaw toward the ship, combines with a screen-fade quad, and respawns Mario if he penetrates the inner radius.
key_stories.outcome: Proof-of-concept works; further tweaks required for background skybox and always-on haze.
key_stories.key_quote: You enter this area and when you look at the ship there’s very strong fog… get too close and the screen fades to white and you’re washed ashore.

key_stories.title: From ROM-hack to Custom Engine
key_stories.summary: Over years Kaze has stripped out most Nintendo code, replacing rendering, animation, physics, camera, and soon the OS and audio.
key_stories.challenge: Legal risk and technical limits of Libultra & vanilla SM64.
key_stories.process: Iteratively rewrote subsystems, e.g., replaced Euler with quaternion animation, recoded slope-aware walking, built 3-D skyboxes, and started a home-brew OS.
key_stories.outcome: Engine is now largely proprietary; only some Mario action functions and audio remain vanilla.
key_stories.key_quote: If I wanted this to be legally sellable, I would have to update the sound engine and change out Mario—almost everything else is already mine.

key_stories.title: Passion vs. Commission
key_stories.summary: Kaze balances paid hacks (e.g., Drug Boss Mario) with RTYI, a labor-of-love project.
key_stories.process: Takes commissions for unconventional hacks that fund living expenses, while dedicating unpaid hours to RTYI.
key_stories.outcome: RTYI stays free and uncompromised; commissions support continued work.
key_stories.key_quote: There’s a lot of money to be made in ROM-hacking, but this one here is just me working because of passion.
